ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I primarily learned to speak and read with more fluency.

I gained a deeper knowledge of French grammar, especially more spoken fluency, which I struggled with a lot before this course. There is also a heavy focus on reading comprehension, so I learned a lot about how to use my knowledge of the French language to talk about stories and events.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The reading materials for this course of in general, quite good and quite interesting. It is really good that in this course you must and get to speak a lot because it helps develop your fluency a lot. A weakness is the reading workload because there can be anywhere from 10-60 pages of reading (of various difficulties), but the amount is so high that it can be hard to get it all done.

You learn a lot of French really quickly. I feel fluent in a way I didn't before taking this class, and my vocabulary has expanded a lot, not just from what we learned in quizzes but also passively from readings. You get out of the class what you put into it. The workload is very reasonable, especially in proportion to how much it teaches.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: It is the. next course for many people in the French series, so there is not a ton of choice with that. If you took French 3, this class had less work than that!

If you're looking at this course after having taken French 130, you're going to find that the workload (e.g., the homework) is lighter, but also far more in-depth, as you're expected to have a better grasp on the readings. Most of the class time is spent on group discussions. If you usually like to sit back and let other students answer questions, you're going to find yourself put on the spot a lot. At first I found this to be pretty nerve-racking, but it really does help with fluency.
